bestBHT.bht: Titus's deep affection for the Corinthians is evident as his heart is more abundantly turned towards them, remembering their obedience and how they received him with fear and trembling. Despite opposition, Titus achieved a remarkable victory, as even those who initially opposed Paul trembled at his words. The Corinthians' humble willingness to obey and rectify any harm done brought Titus great joy. This emphasizes that the true satisfaction for a faithful pastor lies not in worldly pleasures, but in the reverent acceptance of the message of salvation.

Henry Alford: And his heart is more abundantly (turned) toward you, remembering as he does the obedience of you all.
Fear and trembling,' i.e. 'lest ye should not pay enough regard to my injunctions and honour enough his mission from me.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: fear and trembling—with trembling anxiety to obey my wishes
fearful lest there should be aught in yourselves to offend him and me
Albert Barnes: He has become deeply and tenderly attached to you.
His affectionate regard for you has been greatly increased by his visit.
With fear of offending, and with deep apprehension of the consequences of remaining in sin.
John Calvin: He wished, however, to express emphatically the idea, that while Titus had loved the Corinthians previously, he had been, at that time, more vehemently stirred up to love them; and that, from the innermost affections of his heart."

By these words he sometimes expresses simply respect, and this perhaps would not suit ill with this passage, though I should have no objection to view trembling as mentioned particularly to mean, that, being conscious of having acted amiss, they were afraid to face him.

Assuredly, it is not sumptuous banquets, it is not splendid apparel, it is not courteous and honorable salutations, it is not the plaudits of the multitude, that gratify the upright and faithful pastor. He experiences, on the other hand, an overflowing of delight when the doctrine of salvation is received with reverence from his mouth.
Philip Schaff: And his inward affection is more abundantly toward you, whilst he remembereth the obedience of you all, how with fear and trembling ye received him..."

How, instead of receiving him with cold suspicion, with a haughty disposition to justify yourselves and resent his interference, ye received him with a trembling anxiety to yield implicit obedience to whatever might be deemed necessary to repair the injury that had been done.
No wonder, then, that he adds, as a closing word...
Archibald T. Robertson: A remarkable statement of the complete victory of Titus in spite of a stubborn minority still opposing Paul.
He had brought a stern message and they had trembled at the words of Titus.
Paul had himself come to the Corinthians at first with a nervous dread.
John Gill: And his inward affection is more abundant toward you...
...whilst he remembereth the obedience of you all...
...how with fear and trembling you received him...

bhtAttempts.bht: In 2 Corinthians 7:15, the apostle Paul describes how Titus's heart was turned towards the Corinthians with deep affection, remembering their obedience as they received him with fear and trembling. This refers to the Corinthians' anxious desire to obey Paul's instructions and honor Titus's mission. Despite a stubborn minority opposing Paul, Titus achieved a complete victory, as even those who were initially apprehensive trembled at his words. It is clear that Titus's affection for the Corinthians grew after his visit, as they received him with a humble willingness to obey and repair any harm that had been done. This demonstrates the importance of a pastor's delight in the reception of the gospel message rather than worldly pleasures or applause.

In this passage, Paul speaks about Titus's heartfelt attachment to the Corinthians, as his inward affection is abundantly turned towards them, impressed by their obedience and how they received him with fear and trembling. Despite opposition and Paul's initial nervousness when dealing with the Corinthians, Titus's visit resulted in their humble willingness to obey and rectify any wrongs. This shows that true joy for a faithful pastor lies not in earthly rewards but in the reverent acceptance of the message of salvation.

Titus's affection for the Corinthians grew deeply, as his heart turned more abundantly towards them, recalling their obedience and how they received him with fear and trembling. Despite opposition and Paul's initial anxiety, Titus achieved a remarkable victory, as the Corinthians humbly yielded to his instructions. This highlights the pastor's delight when the message of salvation is received with reverence. It is not worldly pleasures or commendation that satisfy the faithful pastor, but the sincere acceptance of the gospel from their lips.

Despite opposition and Paul's initial anxiety, Titus achieved a remarkable victory, as the Corinthians humbly yielded to his instructions. This highlights the pastor's delight when the message of salvation is received with reverence. It is not worldly pleasures or commendation that satisfy the faithful pastor, but the sincere acceptance of the gospel from their lips.

Titus's deep affection for the Corinthians is evident as his heart is more abundantly turned towards them, remembering their obedience and how they received him with fear and trembling. Despite opposition, Titus achieved a remarkable victory, as even those who initially opposed Paul trembled at his words. The Corinthians' humble willingness to obey and rectify any harm done brought Titus great joy. This emphasizes that the true satisfaction for a faithful pastor lies not in worldly pleasures, but in the reverent acceptance of the message of salvation.
